Supplies of rice are gotten in Ségou from vendors of Siribala; the peanuts, from the grand marketplace of Ségou; the bananas, home-delivered by suppliers. Sales are made to customers composed of men, women, and children, cash or credit accepted, at the house, along the asphalt in Ségou Coura, door-to-door, and at the district marketplace.

The group members intend to realize an average monthly profit of 38,000 francs CFA that will be used to make payments on the loan interest and to the tontines (community revolving savings and loan associations). Their ambition is to have a house for living in.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, peanuts, and bananas

loans.name: Rano

texts.en:
N. Rano has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2004 when she first applied for a business development loan. Rano started the business practically from the scratch and, thanks to the previous loans, she could succeed in the business in spite of hard competition.

Rano lives in Khujand and trades in the biggest local bazaar. Rano sells food products. She is a very kind woman. Despite the fact that she single-handedly brings up three children, she is full of enthusiasm and readiness to work hard to ensure a good future for her children.

Rano applies to Kiva for business financial support with a business support loan of 4,100 STJ for 4 months for importing seasonal wares (ice-cream and drinks). Rano thanks Kiva for its support of small business development.

loans.use: To import seasonal wares (ice-cream and drinks)

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Since 1984, Veronica A. has worked as a trader selling tomatoes at Sekondi Market near Shama Junction. She is a widow with two children and has received an education through senior high school. Because her husband is deceased, she is the sole provider for her children and primarily responsible for the upkeep of the house. Her loan will be used to purchase tomatoes in bulk which she will then resell. Veronica hopes to save some of the new profits and also to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase tomatoes in bulk

loans.name: Uguljon

texts.ru: Сангинова  Угулжон - женщина 54-ми лет,  замужем,  имеет  4-х  детей.  Занимается продажей лекарственных  препаратов  и  медикаментов  на центральном рынке Спитаменского рынка.  Она имеет большой  опыт  в  этой  сфере.  Она  привозит  товар  из  города  Истаравшана,  где  расположен  оптовый  рынок.  Её  старший  сын  помогает  ей  привозить  и  продавать  товар. Угулжон  очень  любит  свою  работу.  Она  мечтает  о  том,  что  её  сын  Дильшод  выучившись  на  фармацевта  откроет  свою аптеку.  В  настоящее  время  она  копит  деньги  для  его  обучения.
texts.en:
Uguljon S. is a 54-year-old woman, who is married and has four children. She sells medicine and medical supplies at the Spitamen regional central market, and has a great deal of experience in this line of work. Uguljon brings her goods in from the town of Istaravshan, where there is a wholesale market. Her oldest son helps out on the buying trips and selling the merchandise. Uguljon really loves her work. Her dream is that her son Dilshod would study to become a pharmacist and open his own pharmacy. At the present time, Uguljon is saving money for his education.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory expansion

loans.name: Luz Amelia

texts.es:
Primer préstamo: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=89346&_tpos=2&_tpg=1
Luz Amalia es socia del bancomunal Maria de la Paz.
Desde hace quince años Tiene una bodega donde vende gas, y sigue haciendo movilidad escolar con su esposo, estos meses ha podido compra un carro mas, le agradece a Dios por que esta surgiendo en su negocio.  
En Finca tiene la oportunidad para surgir como mujer, les enseñan a ahorrar y
Necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles,  para compra de gas y abarrotes para su bodega.
El sueño de Luz es tener una flota de taxis.
texts.en:
First loan: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=89346&_tpos=2&_tpg=1 Luz Amalia is a member of the Maria de la Paz communal bank. For fifteen years she has had a store where she sells gas canisters, and she continues to run a school transportation service with her husband. In recent months she has been able to purchase an additional car, and thanks God because her business is expanding. In Finca she has the opportunity to grow as a woman, they teach her to save money. She needs a loan of 2000 soles to purchase gas and groceries for her shop. Luz's dream is to run a taxi company.

Translated from Spanish by Kristen Beck, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase gas and groceries for her store

loans.name: Salina

texts.en:
Salina V. is 37 years old. She lives in Barangay Bimonton of Mallig, Isabela. She is married to Villamor, who is 41 years old. In the village, she manages a general store and a hog-raising business.

Salina is asking the support of Kiva lenders to further improve her two businesses so that she is able to give her four children a prosperous living. She is requesting to borrow the amount of PHP5, 000 as additional capital. Salina says that she will utilize the loan wisely so that her business will be blessed more.

loans.use: To use as business capital for her general store and to raise hogs.

loans.name: Alma Nidia

texts.es:
En la ciudad de León, la señora Alma Nidia V. con gran esfuerzo se dedica a su negocio de venta de comida la cual es preparada por ella misma en su localidad donde es muy visitada por sus clientes porque les gusta los alimentos que ella prepara.

Como todo negocio en desarrollo requiere de la inversión para crecer, la señora Alma necesita invertir para la compra de la materia prima para elaborar los alimentos y así venderlos a sus clientes en su localidad.
texts.en:
In the city of León, Mrs. Alma Nidia V. works hard at her business of preparing and selling food. Her customers frequent her vending location because they enjoy the food she makes.

Like any developing business, Mrs. Alma’s venture needs capital to grow. She needs to purchase ingredients to prepare her meals and sell them to the customers in her area.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients

loans.name: Demberel

texts.en:
Demberel T. is a 34-year-old married mother of one daughter. Her family lives in a "ger" (yurt) district in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her only daughter, Munhzul, age 13, attends a local elementary school. Demberel's husband, Erdenbaatar, is a hard worker in South Korea.

Since 2000, Demberel has been running a butcher stall at the Narantuul, the biggest food market in the capital city. Her sister ran a butcher shop when Demberel decided to open a retail business 9 years ago. Then her sister helped her to start this business. She purchases whole animal meats, especially beef, at wholesale prices and then cuts the meat and resells it in her stall.

Demberel's dream is to expand her small business by opening a bigger butcher shop that sells a variety of meats, including sheep, goat, mutton and camel meat. She is requesting a loan to purchase whole beef to increase her business inventory.

loans.use: To purchase whole beef for her business

loans.name: Siempre Amigas Group

texts.es: El grupo “Siempre Amigas” esta representada por la señora Maria Jesús y conformada por 14 socios que han demostrado ser muy dinámicas puesto que desean realizar actividades para confraternizar y unirse mas como grupo; las señoras tienen una amistad desde hace mucho tiempo ya que se conocen de sus actividades comerciales y son vecinas del mismo barrio. La mayoría de los miembros de grupo desempeñan diferentes tipos de actividades comerciales y de servicio como salones de belleza, tienda de abarrotes, venta de comida, venta de cosméticos por catálogos  y en cuanto los socios se dedican a actividades como mecánico automotriz y otro presta servicios de limpieza en general los socios desarrollan sus actividades en su domicilio y el resto son ambulantes sin puesto fijo. En cuanto al entorno competitivo los socios tienes clientes que se fidelizan gracias a su buen trabajo o por contar con productos de calidad. El destino del financiamiento de para la adquisición de mercadería para surtir sus tiendas, insumos y materiales para agrandar sus negocios y herramientas que ayuden a realizar un trabajo de mayor calidad yen menor tiempo.  Sus expectativas son tener mayores ingresos para brindarles a sus familias una mejor calidad de vida así como tener una economía más estable. A pesar de estar en su primer ciclo los miembros del grupo cuentan con experiencia en grupos solidaR. gracias a créditos con otras instituciones financieras similares a la fundación Agrocapital.
texts.en:
The group “Siempre Amigas” [“Always Friends”] is represented by Maria Jesus and composed of 14 members that have proven to be very dynamic given that they wish to carry out activities to become closer and more united with the group. The women have been friends for a very long time given that they know each other from their businesses and live in the same neighborhood. The majority of the group members run different business and provide different services, such as, beauty shops, grocery stores, food sales, cosmetics sales by catalog, while one of the male group members works as an auto mechanic and the other provides cleaning services. Generally the group members run their businesses out of their homes, and the rest work as mobile vendors without a fixed locale. As far as the competitive market is concerned, the group members have loyal clients thanks to their good work or because they provide quality products. The loan will be used to acquire merchandise to stock their stores, to purchase supplies and materials to expand their businesses, and to acquire tools that will help them carry out work of higher quality in less time. Their expectations are to gain better incomes so that they can offer their families a better quality of life while being in a stable economic situation. Even though they are in their first loan cycle, the group members count on experience in solidarity groups thanks to loans that they have received from other financial institutions similar to the Agrocapital Foundation.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operation capital (to purchase merchandise, supplies, materials, and tools).

loans.name: Fatou Idy

texts.fr: Fatou Idy S. est une femme de 59 ans, elle est mariée et a la charge de 2 enfants dont une est à l'école. C'est une femme très dynamique et participe beaucoup au développement de son terroir en animant des émissions éducatives en langue locale au niveau de la radio. Elle est également présidente de son Banc Villageois dont elle est membre depuis 8 ans. Les revenus de son commerce lui servent à prendre en charge la scolarité de sa fille et les autres besoins de la famille
texts.en:
Fatou Idy S. is a 59-year-old married woman who has two children to support.  One of them is in school.  A very energetic woman, she contributes a great deal to developing her terrain while hosting educational radio broadcasts in the local language.  She is also the president of her village lending group, in which she has been a member for eight years.  The revenues from her business are used to meet the schooling needs of her daughter and the needs of the family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering her commerce

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma E. is from the village of Saray in Iligan City. She is 36 years old. Alma is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Alma makes and sells snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Alma has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Alma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alma is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Alma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her food business.

loans.name: Vanny

texts.en: Mrs. Vanny K. lives in Si Sla village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Khuon Chea Van, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice. In this plantation, they face an obstacle because their field is infertile soil. Thus, Mrs. Vanny K. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field to make the crop more productive. She is 51 years old and the mother of five children, one of whom is a recycling collector while the others two are farmers and the remaining two are attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo. Her husband is shown on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field to make the crop more productive.

loans.name: Joana

texts.en:
Joana is forty years old. She is divorced and has given birth to five children who are all in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a busy commercial/farming community in the Brong Ahafo Region called Goaso.

Joana is a trader. She trades in cosmetics. She sells on a table top at the local market square and also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. Joana sometimes hawks to sell in her community. She buys her goods such as pomade, powder, etc. from Kumasi. She has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics

loans.name: Nasser

texts.en: Nasser has been the owner of a bakery called "Nasser Bakery" since 2006. He services the neighboring villages with delicious breads. Recently, he decided to make bread deliveries to homes. That's why he needs a loan of $1,200 to purchase a Rapid Car to make his idea work, so he can deliver his products and make a good income.

loans.use: To purchase a Rapid Car to make deliveries

loans.name: Germina

texts.en:
Germina is a 78 year old widowed mother of 7 children aged between 46 and 58 years.  None of her children goes to school. She owns and resides in a four-roomed house, where she is staying with ten people. Germina takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.  Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and buying medication.  

Germina works seven days a week.  She owns a pub in Mengo Kisenyi, and incurs transportation costs to and from Owino, one of the busiest markets in Kampala city. She receives an average of 10 customers a day and works to sell to all categories of people. Her major business challenges include the ever-increasing price of beer and the rainy season, which hinders her customers from reaching her because she works in a muddy place.  She has been in this business for thirty years and with MCDT – who are servicing her tenth loan – for five.  Germina joined MCDT because it was near her home and was easy to work with. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer . She hopes to see her business grow bigger so she can start dealing exclusively in wholesale.

loans.use: to buy more crates of beer

loans.name: Francisca Mwikali

texts.en: Francisca Mwikali is 42 years old and married with three children. She has a shop where she makes curtains to sell to customers as well as making custom orders. She has been in the business for about ten years and earns a profit of about 60,000 KES per month. Francisca wants to use the loan to buy more fabric and materials for making curtains. She has never borrowed from another micro-finance institute and was introduced to KADET by a friend. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy fabric and materials to make curtains for customers

loans.name: Lucia Isabel

texts.es: La señora  Lucia G.  tiene 31 años de edad, es Casada  habita junto  a su esposo  e hijos, ella y su esposo se dedican al mismo oficio llevan 12 años de laborar en la artesanía  “Confección de delantales Típicos para mujeres” su residencia que se encuentra en el Caserío Xetinimit de la Aldea Nimasac, del departamento y municipio de Totonicapán, Guatemala,  actualmente, por las condiciones económicas en que se encuentra  no son suficientes para poder cubrir su necesidad, por tal razón acudió a la Asociación ASDIR, a solicitar un préstamo, con la intención de comprar materia prima y de esa manera poder aumentar sus ventas, esperando también poder sacar adelante a su familia, y que tengan mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Lucia G., 31, is married and lives with her husband and children. She and her husband have been artisans for the last 12 years. They weave "Typical Aprons for Women" in their home, which is in the Xetinimit settlement in Nimasac village, in the department and municipality of Totonicapán, Guatemala. Because of her current economic situation, she is unable to cover basic expenses so she has called upon Asociación ASDIR to request financing to buy raw materials so that she can increase sales hoping, too, to advance her family and to have better living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials.

loans.name: Tom

texts.en:
Mr. Tom T., 49, and his wife, Mrs. Vanna Nheak (pictured together), 41, have been married since 1984 and have eight children: seven sons and one daughter. One of the children is married and lives in a separate home, four help their parents in their farming business and the three youngest sons are in school. The family lives on National Road number one approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.
 
Mr. Tom T. and his wife have been growing rice and cucumbers for more than 25 years. Besides farming, Tom is a fisherman as well. He has applied for a Kiva loan one time already. He now is requesting his second loan of $1,200 to buy a motorbike for commuting. He also will use a part of his loan to buy fertilizer, pesticides and fuel oil for his farm to continue increasing his productivity.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle, fertilizer, pesticides and fuel oil

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Mrs. Rosalie D. is from the village of Lucos, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 26 years old, is married, and is blessed with two infant children.

Rosalie owns and operates a business providing transportation services as shown in the photo. She is shown with her husband and one of her children.

In 2008, Rosalie joined PMPC to gain financial assistance. She is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital in purchasing another motorcycle. She wants to earn additional income by having another motorcycle for hire.

Rosalie wishes to save for their future and for the education of her children.

loans.use: To purchase another motorcycle for hire

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Mrs. Ly S. was born in 1963. She has been married for many years to Smanel, 59, who is a taxi driver. They have 3 children. One is married and lives away from home. The other two are single and work in the garment industry. Ly S. sells clothes that she buys from her wholesale supplier. Ly S. faces possible health problems resulting from polluted water surrounding her house. She requests a loan to purchase fill dirt to improve the condition of her property. (Ly S. was not available when the photo was taken so her husband is shown instead.)

loans.use: To purchase fill dirt

loans.name: Rolan

texts.en:
Rolan O.'s main source of income comes from providing transport services with his motor vehicle. He is 40 years old, married and has school-age children. They are from the village of San Antonio, Talakag, Bukidnon. Rolan has been in his business for over eight years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2010, Rolan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Rolan is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide more better service. This will be his first loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue to improve his business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide more better  service

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice loves cooking and that is why she commercialized her cooking skills to yield money. She sells Nigerian cooked foods and drinks. She loves this business because she does not sell on credit to her customers. She does not want to incur debt in her business. She hopes to grow her business. 

She hopes for a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell. She is 42 years old and married to a building contractor. They are blessed with four children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en:
Pheng Y., age 29, is married and resides with her five-year-old child in Takeo province, Cambodia.

Y. is engaged in a business sewing clothes, earning an income of 3 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband (pictured) is a construction worker, earning an income of 3 USD per day. Their standard of living has been improved since Y. and her husband have had these businesses.

Y. is requesting a loan of 500 USD to purchase calves to raise for sale. This is her second loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy calves to raise and sell

loans.name: Trinidad E's Group

texts.en:
Trinidad E C. is from the village of Camanga,Tukuran ZDS. She is 52 years old. Trinidad is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both collectively responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if one is delinquent or defaults.

Trinidad is married and has seven adult children. To make a living, Trinidad owns & operates a farm. The main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting rice for sale. Trinidad has been engaged in her business for over 21 years and earns approximately 9,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2009, Trinidad joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Trinidad's group is requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Trinidad from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Miraluna

texts.en:
Miraluna B. is from the village of Waterfall, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 38 years old. Miraluna is married and has 2 young children. Miraluna owns & operates a business providing transportation services with the use of their own motor vehicle. Her husband is the driver of the said vehicle. Their business operates for over 6 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Miraluna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Miraluna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. Miraluna decided to request a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to purchase needed materials to provide more better service and motor vehicle maintenance.This will be the 7th loan taken out by Miraluna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase needed materials to provide more better service and motor vehicle maintenance.

loans.name: Ofelia's Group

texts.en:
Ofelia C., aged 42, is from the village of Brgy. Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is the group leader of a 14-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Ofelia is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Ofelia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Ofelia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Ofelia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand the products offered. This will be the eighth loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand the products offered

loans.name: Mamie United Business Group

texts.en:
Mamie W., who is holding the sign in the photograph, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Mamie United Business. She is 33 years old, single, and has two children. She was only able to attend school through 7th grade due to financial difficulties. 

For 3 years, she has been selling lappas (a traditional women's dress) and drinks at the Nezon Market in Harbel, Margibi County, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. 

She plans to use her 4,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 20,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more lappas and drinks. 

Her hope is to expand her business, be financially independent, and to continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more lappas and drinks.

loans.name: Svay

texts.en:
Svay P., 47, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. P. and her husband are farmers, earning an income of about $1 each per day to help cover the family expenses.

One of her children (shown here) is a construction worker, earning an income of about $4 per day. P. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase construction materials to expand her child’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. 

P.'s son (the construction worker) and his family appear in the photograph.

loans.use: to buy construction materials to expand her child's business

loans.name: Laura Amelia

texts.es:
Laura Amelia M. M. tiene 35 años. Vive con sus 2 hijos, Ruth (15) y Génesis (3), en el cantón de Chillanes en la provincia de Bolívar.

Laura es una socia de la ventanilla rural Santa Rosa, que está ubicada a una hora y media del cantón Chillanes. Son 18 socios en total, que en la mayoridad tienen sus propios negocios. Esto es el primer  préstamo que ellos sacan con la Cooperativa San José.

Laura se dedica al cuidado y venta de chanchos, pollos y ganado. También se dedica a las tareas del hogar. Realiza sus compras y ventas en Bucay y Santa Rosa. 

Solicita el préstamo para el mantenimiento de los animales y para comprar medicina para ellos. Su sueño es ampliar una buena granja para los animales. 

Le gusta dedicarse a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Laura Amelia M. M. is 35 years old. She live with her 2 children, Ruth (15) and Génesis (3) in the Chillanes canton in the Bolívar province. Laura is a member of the rural communal bank Santa Rosa. It is located an hour and a half from the Chillanes canton. There are a total of 18 members, of which the majority own their own businesses. This is the first loan that they have requested from the San José Cooperative. Laura raises and sells pigs, chicken and cattle. She also takes care of the household duties. She buys and sells in Bucay and Santa Rosa. She is requesting a loan to help with the maintenance of her animals and to buy medicine for them. Her dream is to expand her farm for her animals. She also likes to devote herself to her children.

Translated from Spanish by Ann Achilli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy medicine for her pigs, chicken and cattle and to help with the maintenance

loans.name: Van

texts.en:
Van S., 21, is married and lives with her husband in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its quality palm products.

S. and her husand are employed at a local sweatshop producing shoes for an income of USD 5 each per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a motorbike to use for commuting to work with her husband.

In the future, S. would like to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for commuting to work

loans.name: Yawa Angèle

texts.fr: K. est une femme mariée et mère d'un enfant. elle vit avec son mari et son époux  dans le quartier de akodessewa qui est un quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé, elle a commencé ce commerce en 2006, sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes. elle souhaite se réapprovisionner face à son stock en baisse raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de  divers produits d'alimentation générale. avec son revenu elle participe aux dépenses de sa famille.
texts.en:
Yawa K. is married with one child and lives with her husband in the Akodessewa quarter which is on the outskirts of the town of Lomé. She created her business in 2006, and her customer base is varied. She would like to boost her inventory and so is seeking a loan from WAGES in order to purchase more food products. She will use her revenue to see to her family's needs.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing general foods

loans.name: Clorinda

texts.es:
Clorinda nació en la ciudad de Ocongate provincia de Quispicanchis del departamento del Cusco y pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Margarita Ocongate” de la asociación Arariwa Cusco. Actualmente, Clorinda vive en la ciudad donde nació junto con su esposo y sus tres hijos de las cuales dos están vivos y uno falleció.  (La ciudad de Ocongate se encuentra ubicada a dos horas de la ciudad del Cusco). 

Hace 12 años, Clorinda  que se dedica  a la crianza de animales menores como por ejemplo cuyes, ella en su domicilio tiene un galpón donde aproximadamente tiene 300 cuyes, ella vende a S/. 20 nuevos soles cada cuy a las personas que tiene restaurantes y a sus vecinas o amigas.  
Clorinda es una persona muy amigable y carismática también se dedica a preparar cuy al horno a las personas que vistan su domicilio. Al lado de su casa, Clorinda tiene varios terrenos de cultivo donde siembra pasto y alfalfa que sirven de alimento para los animales. La pueden encontrar los 7 días de la semana en su domicilio. 
 
Con el próximo préstamo que Clorinda espera recibir S/. 1000 nuevo soles. Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo en comprar semillas y abono. 

Ya son dos años que participa en el banco comunal y le va muy bien gracias a la confianza de sus compañeros y a la puntualidad de los pagos de las cuotas. El sueño de la socia es construir un centro recreacional en su domicilio.
    
La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Clorinda was born in the city of Ocongate, Quispicanchis province, Cusco department. She belongs to the “Las Margaritas Ocongate” (The Ocongate Daisies) Communal Bank with the Arariwa Ascociación of Cusco. Clorinda currently lives with her husband and children in the city where she was born. She had three children, two are living and one died. The city of Ocongate is two hours from the city of Cusco. Clorinda has been raising small animals like guinea pigs for 12 years. She has a shed at home with approximately 200 guinea pigs. She sells them to people who have restaurants and her neighbors and friends for .20 soles each. Clorinda is a very friendly and charismatic person. She also sells baked guinea pigs to the people who visit her house. At the side of her house Clorinda has some fields where she plants grass and alfalfa; they serve as feed for the animals. She can be found seven days a week in her home. With the next loan Cloridna hopes to receive 1,000 soles. She would like to use the money from this loan to buy seeds and fertilizer. She has participated in the communal bank for two years. It is going very well for her thanks to the reliability of her colleagues and the punctuality of their payments. Her dream is to build a recreational area at her house. She is grateful for the opportunity that has been provided and promises to complete her payments by the established deadlines.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Rosadel

texts.en:
Rosadel E. is 61-years old, married and supports her family by operating two business ventures, a general store and e-loading (the sale of pre-paid mobile phone credits). She lives in Phase 3 of Barangay Canturay, a part of Sipalay City, Negros Occidental province in the Vasayas islands. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2001 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and e-loading business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 3500 PHP.

Rosadel is now borrowing 15,000 PHP so that she can purchase more stock for her general store. This will be her eighth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 15,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Rosadel aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a dollar a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. They are on a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon—a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock for her store

loans.name: Deo

texts.en:
K. Deo is a warmly polite 40-year-old married father of five kids who all attend school in Nagatule-Kampala. Selling herbal natural medicines is the business of this courteous and cordial gentleman who had a preference for them on the basis of the high demand for them, especially in most parts of Kampala where people are destitute and cannot afford hospital medication. 

Thirteen years is the time he has been plying this business and it is a business he began with savings from his cooking oil sales savings.  Per week, Deo says he makes profits totaling up to 250,000 shillings. With this loan he wants to improve his business. The first thing he intends to do is get a permanent rental place in town where he will be able to stock his products for sale on a larger scale.

loans.use: Rental fees for a new outlet in town

loans.name: Ailyn

texts.en:
Ailyn M. is a married woman who lives in Sitio Kalubihan, Brgy. San Antonio, Himamaylan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  General Store and Cane Planter (Arendo) businesses. Her husband Eriberto Miguil Jr., who is 33 years old, works as a Tricycle (three-wheeled transport vehicle) Driver to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have two children who are 3 and  9 years old. 

Ailyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ailyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 24,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 12th loan, she is borrowing PHP 26,000, which she intends to use to pay for inventory for her general store so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. 

Ailyn M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Fund Operations

loans.name: Jeannette

texts.en:
Jeannette is 32 years old and single. She sells various items such as beauty soaps, lotions and tomato sauce in her shop. She has been in this business for nine years. She says that her business is successful because her shop is very popular.

With this loan Jeannette will buy more lotions and tomato sauce to sell. With the profits she will purchase new items for sale. In the future she would prefer to have a big shop as a wholesaler.

loans.use: To buy more lotions and tomato sauce to sell

loans.name: Maato Ene

texts.en:
Maato has been rearing livestock to sell in Naivasha town for the last seven years now. She is 24 years old, married to Nkitei Saapai and they have two children.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the cash to buy more sheep, which she will rear and sell later at a profit.

In the future, Maato hopes to diversify her sources of income and open a boutique in town.

loans.use: To buy more sheep to rear and sell later, at a profit.

loans.name: Ozipa

texts.en:
Ozipa S. is a 61-year-old widow with five grown children.  Her youngest son Ramil lives with her and helps in the household. In 1992, Ozipa began her own cattle breeding business with the purchase of two milk cows. She also started to cultivate vegetables on a plot of land. Since then, she has worked hard to improve her harvests and provide high quality products. Ozipa’s efforts have been focused on supporting and expanding her household. Currently, she sells milk products to the local diary factory and earns about 5,000 KGS a month. 

Ozipa is requesting a loan of 50,000 KGS to buy milk cows. With the revenue from this investment, she plans to purchase a horse and a cart for transporting vegetables.

About Bai-Tushum and Partners:
 
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target especially vulnerable populations. It is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that leads to increased employment and meets the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase milk cows

loans.name: Asma's Group

texts.en:
Asma is a talented lady who does embroidery work to support her family financially. Her quality art brings in good income and she fulfills regular orders from her clients every month. She resides with her family in the area named Raja jang, which is a small area in the city of Riwind, located in Punjab province of Pakistan. Asma is 30 years of age, married to S. H., who has a business of making shoes. He has a small shop in the market where he receives orders from different factories and shoe shops to provide finished product to earn an income for his family. 

Asma has 2 sons and 2 daughters. Her oldest son is in kindergarten, while the others are too young to attend school yet. Asma wants to provide quality education to her children. That’s why she works very hard. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her husband in his shoe making business. With the loan he will buy leather, nails and shoe polish in larger quantities. That will enable him to make shoes in bulk quantity to fulfill the orders of his customers and increase his income. He has been in this business for over 10 years. Asma is hopeful that, through an investment, her husband will improve his business further and increase his monthly income. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In her previous loan year, she built good credit behavior and attended every meeting.

loans.use: To buy leather, nails and shoe polish for shoe making business

loans.name: Katsaka

texts.en:
Katsaka is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated a green grocer business, selling at the market and from home to her neighbours. Katsaka faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation in her business. She hopes to open a retail shop in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to renovate her house and purchase sheets of iron building material. She decided to join Yehu to access loans and uplift her living standards.

loans.use: To  renovate her house and purchase sheets of iron building material.

loans.name: Chivas De Corazon Group

texts.es: Este grupo se llama "Chivas de Corazón", está ubicado en el Estado de Morelos en México, en una comunidad que se distingue por su  balneario llamado El Rollo que es un atractivo turístico del estado, el grupo está conformado por 10  integrantes. Lorena Báez es integrante del grupo,ella se dedica a la venta de ropa, negocio que inicio hace 4 años. Solicita su préstamo para comprar más prendas, tiene 36 años, estudió hasta el tercer año de secundaria, es soltera y no tiene hijos, sus clientes están a gusto  porque siempre encuentran lo que necesitan. Al momento de solicitar el préstamo se siente contenta porque con el crédito podrá comprar mercancía para surtir sus pedidos, y tendrá mayores ganancias con las que comprará un aparador  que necesita para su negocio, también espera que su negocio crezca para cuando se case y lleguen los hijos tenga la posibilidad de mandarlos a la escuela y dedicarles tiempo en casa.
texts.en:
This group is called "Chivas de Corazón" and is located in the Mexican state of Morelos, in a community that is known for the "El Rollo" water park, one of the state's major tourist attractions.

The group is comprised of ten members, one of whom is Lorena Báez.  Four years ago, she started a business selling clothing.  She is requesting this loan to buy more garments.  She is 36 years old, studied through the third year of secondary school, is single, and does not have any children.  Her customers like her business because they tend to find what they need.

As she requests this loan, she feels content because this loan will make it possible for her to buy merchandise to fill her customers' requests, and she will bring in more income.  She will use the additional earnings to buy a cupboard she needs for her business.  She also hopes that her business will grow so that when she gets married and has children, it will be possible to send them to school and to dedicate time to them at home.

loans.use: to buy merchandise and stock more items of clothing

loans.name: Elsa's Group

texts.en:
Elsa S. is from the village of Pinoma, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 40 years old. Elsa is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Elsa is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Elsa owns & operates a direct selling business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soaps, toothpaste,& beauty products in the local community. Elsa has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Elsa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Elsa is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Elsa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Fátima Susana

texts.es:
En la ciudadela Bellavista de  Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen las socias del Banco Comunal.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Fátima, ella tiene 55 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene dos hijos mayores de edad, los mismos que estudian en universidad y que  aún viven con ella. Su esposo es médico veterinario y trabaja en la Universidad Laica en Manta.

Es un ama de casa que para obtener sus propios recursos se dedica a la venta de ropa, zapatos y productos de Yanbal (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Trabaja tres días a la semana y su forma de venta es puerta a puerta aunque comenta que también sus clientes llegan a su casa a observar y comprar los productos los mismos que deja a  crédito y cobra cada semana o cada quince de acuerdo a lo que quieran sus clientes. La ropa y zapatos los compra una parte en Guayaquil y lo que es Yanbal lo recibe en su casa.
 
Este crédito es para comprar perfumes, cremas, cosméticos, zapatos y ropa. Este es el cuarto ciclo en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque los créditos  son fáciles de hacer. Sus sueños son tener un carro y un bazar.
texts.en:
In the city of Bellavista de  Portoviejo, capitl of Manabí, long known as the city of the Reales Tamarindos, meet the members of the Communal Bank. 

This is where we met Señora Fátima, she is 55 years old and is married. She and her husband have two older children who both study at the university but live with them. Her husband is a medical veterinarian and he works at the University Laica en Manta.

Señora Fátima is a housewife and to increase her own resources she sells clothes, shoes and Yanbal products (beauty products, cosmetics, perfume and accessories for ladies). She works three days a week, selling door to door but she also reports that her clients come to her house to see and buy her products, these customers pay with credit or charge every week or the 15th of every month, whichever agreement her clients prefer. The clothes and shoes she buys in Guayaquil and the Yanbal products are sent to her house.

This loan is to buy perfumes, creams, cosmetics, shoes, and clothes. This is Señora Fátima's fourth loan cycle with the Communal Bank, she likes working with the bank because the loans are easy to make. Her dream is to have a car and her own store.

loans.use: To buy perfumes, creams, cosmetics, shoes, and clothes.

loans.name: Egon

texts.en:
Mr. Egon is 47 years old.  He is married and has a 4-year-old daughter.  His spouse is Ms. Margarita. She is 43 years old and she works in the house.

Mr. Egon says that he learned his father's work when he was little and thanks to him he can earn a name in a competitive market.  Most of what Mr. Egon makes is home furniture, such as chairs and end tables.  He also makes windows and doors.  

Mr. Egon asked for the foundation's help to buy basic products for his business (cedar, pine and plywood) so he can get more work done for a restaurant.  He thanks the foundation for the trust it has for him.

loans.use: To buy wood (cedar, pine and plywood) to make furniture

loans.name: Nancy Marlene

texts.es:
Nancy, reside en Berlín departamento de Usulután, se dedica a la venta de ropa y cosméticos, tiene 37 años de edad, vive con su padre un señor de 68 años de edad y una hermana de 23 años; El negocio lo inicio hace 10 años, por iniciativa propia, y lo tiene ubicado en el Mercado Municipal de Berlín, el horario de venta es de 7:00am a 5:00pm.
Actualmente está solicitando un préstamo para comprar mercadería: Blusas, faldas, toallas, lociones, maquillaje y demás productos de belleza, con esta inversión Nancy espera fortalecer el negocio, ver la posibilidad de tener más ventas e ir progresando.
Las aspiraciones de ella es tener el negocio amplio y fuerte en mercadería, que el servicio a los clientes sea cada vez más eficiente y mejorar el sistema de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Nancy lives in Berlín in the department of Usulután, and sells clothing and cosmetics.  She is 37 years old and lives with her father who is 68 and her sister, 23.  She set up her business 10 years ago on her own initiative and is located in the Municipal Market of Berlín.  Her business hours are from 7:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.

She is requesting the loan to buy merchandise such as blouses, skirts, towels, lotions, make-up and other beauty products.  With this investment Nancy hopes to strengthen her business and increase sales so she can get ahead.

She aspires to having a broad range of merchandise and to be increasingly efficient when it comes to her customers, as well as improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy blouses, skirts, towels, lotions, make-up and other beauty products

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: The woman in the photo is Mrs. Pen T., age 38, who lives in the province of Kompong Tom, Cambodia, where she earns a living raising pigs. Since 2000, she has run this business and it has provided her with income to attain her standard of living. She is married with six children, two of whom are single and the rest are married and live in their own house. Her husband earns a living by providing band services to his neighbors and other villagers in and around his community. Mrs. Pen T. is going to use her loan to add to her current savings to buy a piece of farm land near her house. She will use this land for her farming business or to rent out to farmers for a fee.

loans.use: To buy a piece of farm land

loans.name: Virginia's Group

texts.en: Virginia D. G. is from the village of Villa Pascua, Diffun, Quirino. She is 53 years old. Virginia is the group leader of a 12-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Virginia D. G.'s group. Virginia is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Virginia raises pigs for fattening and sale. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Virginia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the third loan taken out by Virginia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Kom

texts.en:
Kom H. earns a living by distilling alcohol at her home in Siem Reap province. She has been in the business of distilling alcohol since she was young and unmarried. She typically generates a revenue of US $6 each day to cover the family’s needs. Her husband earns an income by utilizing a cultivating machine to provide a tapping rice service for other farmers. They are the devoted parents of five children, two of whom are married. 

One of Kom H.’s children works as a security guard and has a fixed salary of around $80 per month. He  goes to work by hiring a motor taxi every day, which means he is forced to spend some of his profit for traveling expenses. In order to reduce the cost of traveling, Kom H. has decided to ask for a loan in order to purchase a motorcycle for her son to commute to work.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle so that her son can commute to work

loans.name: Hugo Marcelo

texts.es: El señor Hugo es mecánico con mas de 15 años de experiencia  y actualmente cuenta con un taller propio, es padre de una niña de 4 meses pero aun no vive con la madre de su hija por circunstancias ajenas, tiene su taller en la zona de Irpavi esta  es la primera vez que solicita un crédito ya que  en este momento necesita el dinero para la compra de una maquina (pluma extractor para la reparación de motor), es en lo que utilizara el dinero del crédito, es una persona muy trabajadora, con deseos de superación, tiene  mucha clientela ya que le buscan por su buen trabajo, y con esta nueva maquina piensa ampliar su negocio y crecer  gracias a la institución, esta muy agradecido con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
Hugo is a mechanic with more than 15 years experience.  He currently owns his own garage.  He is the father of a 4 month-old girl although he doesn't live with his daughter's mother due to circumstances beyond his control.  His garage is located in Irpavi.  This is the first time that Hugo has requested a loan as right now he needs money to buy a machine (an extractor for repairing engines).  This is what he will use his loan money to buy.

Hugo is a very hard-working person who has a desire to improve himself.  He has a lot of customers who seek him out because of the good work that he does.  With this new machine, he is planning to expand and grow his business.  He is very grateful to the institution for the support they have given him.

loans.use: to buy machinery (an extractor for repairing engines)

loans.name: Stephen Kiarie

texts.en:
Stephen Kiarie, 32, is married to Jane Wanjiku who also contributes to the family income. He has one child who is three years old. He has been in the business of selling construction items for a period of about six years with an income of about 15,000 Kenyan shillings a month. 

This is his third loan with KADET after successfully repaying the previous one. He wants to use the loan to buy more cement for the business. He hopes to own a bigger hardware store, venture into agriculture, and improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: to buy cement.

loans.name: Sandra Maria

texts.es: Sandra Maria posee un negocio que es venta de recargas telefónicas y alquiler de triciclos. Tiene más de 6 años en este negocio, ha buscado como mantener a sus 2 hijos este negocio lo aprendió por la necesidad de sufragar los gastos del hogar, es una persona muy luchadora y disfruta de su actividad. Solicita este financiamiento para realizarle mejoras a triciclo comprar llantas, asientos, forros y recargas telefónicas. El desea con mejorar su capital y proporcionar más ingresos para su hogar.
texts.en:
Sandra María has a business selling telephone recharge time cards and leasing tricycles.  She’s been in business 6 years.  She has sought ways to support her two children.  She learned this business because of the need she had to meet household expenses.  She’s a very tenacious person who enjoys her work.

She is asking for this loan to do some improvements on the tricycle: to buy tires, seats and seat covers.  She will also buy more telephone recharge cards.  She hopes to improve her capital and provide more income for her home.

loans.use: to buy tires, seats and seat covers for her tricycle and to buy telephone time cards.

loans.name: Jorgina

texts.es: La señorita  Jorgina es originaria del estado de Puebla, México, ella tiene 27 años de edad, ella es soltera sin hijos, ella se dedica a trabajar en la alfarería elabora cazuelas con su papas y su hermano, ella solicito su crédito para comprar leña, barro, greta y pintura para la elaboración de las cazuelas, a ella desde muy pequeña sus papas le enseñaron a trabajar el barro, ella inicio su negocio hace 10 años con unos ahorros que tenia, su negocio es familiar y se siente orgullosa de trabajar la alfarería porque es de generaciones y es un trabajo que le da para comer y para los gastos de su casa, ella y sus papas salen a vender sus productos a las ferias y las utilidades las utiliza comprando mas material, ella está contenta con el préstamo que va a recibir porque va a comprar el material para seguir trabajando, los desafíos que enfrenta su negocio son las lluvias no pueden trabajar bien no se secan las cazuelas, en San Marcos todos trabajamos el barro elaborando la loza, siembran en tiempos de lluvias maíz y sorgo, el día 25 y 26 de abril celebran la Fiesta del Pueblo San Marcos, hacen misas, procesión y baile. Ella quiere decirle a Kiva y a Fundación Realidad “gracias por este préstamo ya que nos ayuda en los negocio para que sigamos adelante”.
texts.en:
Jorgina, 27, is from the State of Puebla, México.  She is single and has no children. She is a potter; she makes pots with her parents and brother.  

She asked for the loan to buy firewood, clay, “greta” (chemical mixture of copper oxide and lead) and paint to make the pots.  Her parents taught her how to work clay when she was still a little girl.  She started her business ten years ago with some savings she had.  Her business is a family business and she’s proud to be a potter because it’s been their occupation for generations and it’s work that provides food for her and to cover household expenses.  

She and her parents go the various farmers markets to sell their wares and use profits to buy more raw materials to continue working.  The challenge she faces is the rain because it keeps the pots from drying properly and they can’t work.  In San Marcos we all work clay manufacturing the dinnerware.  During the rainy season they farm corn and sorghum.  On the 25th and 26th of April they celebrate the town’s feast day of St. Mark; they have masses, a procession and a dance.  

She wants to say to Kiva and to Fundación Realidad: ”Thank you for this loan because it is of great help to us to continue in business.”

loans.use: to buy firewood, clay, paint and other supplies to make pots.

location.town: Barrio San Pedro, Acteopan, Estado de Puebla

loans.name: Arnold

texts.en:
This is Arnold, 30 years old and a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. He is married to Marcialuz, a housewife and mother to their three children. The family manages their own household while operating the business. Arnold is working hard to continually provide income for the family's everyday expenses and his children’s schooling. Arnold believes, like most poor Filipino parents, that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children, as he himself has been an undergraduate.

Arnold operates a variety store, which, in the Philippines, is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, PHP 5 worth of cooking oil or an egg. Arnold earns an income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. His store is located adjacent to his house and his regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of PHP 800 in daily sales.

To help him continue operations of his business, Arnold is requesting a PHP8,000 loan. He will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand his product inventory. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business. 

Arnold hopes to be able to expand soon, just as he fervently hopes that his children will be able to graduate one day and finish their studies. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery products and inventory items

loans.name: Tweimukye Nkenda Group

texts.en:
Sirasi is 42 years old and married with eight children between the ages of 9 and 18 years old. He has no other dependents and he owns a semi-permanent house where he lives with 10 people in Karuguuza, Uganda. For five years, Sirasi has been running a retail shop and from it, he has been able to build a commercial house. He faces the challenge of a high inflation rate but hopes to expand his business to wholesale. He needs a loan to buy sugar, salt and soap to sell.

Sirasi is holding a yellow card in the photo.

loans.use: to buy sugar, salt and soap to sell.

loans.name: Masiphile Group

texts.en:
Nonhlanhle is 42 years old and single. She has 6 young children, 3 of whom attend school. She also cares for two family members who live with her in the town of Empangeni, South Africa. She has been running a retail business for the last year, selling fried dough, chips, ice cream, sandwich meat, and sweets to children at her local school. She also receives support from a grant issued by the South African government to help raise her children.

Nonhlanhle has requested a loan through WDB and Kiva to purchase more stock for her business. She has a lot of demand from the children at her local school, and her business has been growing very quickly. She would eventually like to open a proper store near the school to sell her products. She thinks that this loan will improve her life by increasing the profits she makes from her business. Nonhlanhle is a new client of WDB and Kiva and she is hoping for a better future. In the photo she is pictured raising her hand.

loans.use: to purchase snacks and other foods for resale.

loans.name: Kadzo

texts.en:
Kadzo is  a 44-year-old widow with four grown-up children.  She is a fish monger and  has been in this business for the last sixteen  years.

This her third loan with KADET, which she will use to purchase more fish to resell. She plans to use the anticipated profit to service this KADET loan given that her previous loans had been successfully repaid. 

She hopes to see her family prosper through KADET loans.

loans.use: purchase more fish for resale

loans.name: Maruja

texts.es: Maruja es socia del Banco Comunal María De Los Angeles, es socia de Finca Perú desde hace 3 ciclos, tiene 4 hijos y trabaja en artesanía al igual que su esposo, ellos compran piedras para poder tallarlas y también tienen un Stand en el Mercado de Artesanías, solicita un prestamo para invertir en su negocio, incrementar sus ventas y mejorar su negocio. Agradece a Finca Perú porque ha aprendido a ahorrar, las capacitaciones ayudaron para que pueda valorarse como mujer y ser mejor madre y esposa.
texts.en:
Maruja is a member of the Communal Bank “María de Los Ángeles”. She has been a member of FINCA Peru for three loan cycles. Maruja has four children and works in a handicraft business alongside her husband. They buy stones to carve and also manage a booth at the craft market.

Maruja is requesting a loan to invest in her business so that she can make improvements and increase her sales. She is grateful to FINCA Peru because she has learned how to save. The training seminars have helped her to value herself as a woman and to become a better wife and mother.

loans.use: to buy materials for her business.

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester is 45 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has four children. 

Ester has a shop that sells animal feed by the kilogram. She has had this business for seven years. She has requested a loan for PHP 6,000 to buy sacks of animal feed for sale.

Ester has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy sacks of animal feed for sale.

loans.name: Harutyun

texts.en:
Harutyun was born in 1978. He lives in Vazashen village with his jobless wife and retired parents. 

Since 1990, Harutyun’s family has been engaged in farming. Now Harutyun is doing the major part of the farm work and thus supporting his family. He breeds goats, a cow and a calf. Harutyun sells goat’s milk and cheese to fellow villagers. Also he grows fruits and vegetables for his family. 

Harutyun intends to develop his farm and he is asking for a 600,000 AMD loan to buy some chickens, rabbits, calves and piglets. Also he will buy fodder for his farm animals. 

This is Harutyn’s second loan from Nor Horizon.

loans.use: To buy some chickens, rabbits, calves, piglets, and fodder.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda is married with four children. Imelda is 53 years old and lives in Molave Zamboanga Del Sur.

To earn a living, Imelda has a general store business. She has had this business for 26 years. Each month, she earns approximately PHP 8,000. She requested a loan of PHP 7,000 to pay the tuition for her daughter in college. Imelda has been a member of PMPC for two years.

In the future, Imelda hopes to earn 20,000 PHP a month this year.

loans.use: to pay the college tuition for her daughter

loans.name: Concejo

texts.en:
Concejo is 46 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 5 children.

Concejo has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has had this business for 5 years. She requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Concejo is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Concejo hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a 26 years old married woman with three children who attend school.

She selling charcoal in South Sudan and has been in business for five years.

Rose requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase more charcoal to sell.  Rose says the extra income will helps her pay for her children to go to school.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Erdeneochir

texts.en:
Erdeneochir is 22 years old and lives with his wife in ger, a Mongolian nomadic tent, in Hovd province of Mongolia. His wife rents a well and runs it. He started his taxi service business in 2007 with his own car. Now that winter is approaching, he needs to finish building the house and service his car for a harsh winter. He is a young and hard working man who says, "My daughter has born recently. I don't want my daughter turn out to be like me, in order to make that possible, I will work hard and get her well educated". 

He is requesting 3,500,000 MNT to buy spare parts for his car and to finish building his house.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his taxi and finish building his house

loans.name: Haydee De Jesús

texts.es: Haydee de Jesús es comerciante y su actividad es la venta de ropa típica nacional teniendo dos tiendas en el mercado municipal que es donde percibe sus ingresos para la manutención de su hogar. Una de las tiendas es atendida por ella con una muchacha que le ayuda y la otra la atiende su hija junto con otra muchacha que le ayuda. Es madre soltera que ha luchado para obtener el bienestar de su hogar. El crédito lo solicita para invertirlo en su negocio de ropa y zapatos y por la temporada que se avecina, necesita invertir en otros productos como lo son los navideños. Menciona que los anteriores créditos que ha tenido con Ceprodel le han servido de mucho ya que antes tenía solo una tienda y ahora ya tiene dos y bien surtida de ropa variada.
texts.en: Haydee de Jesús is a merchant who sells traditional Nicaraguan clothing in two stores in the municipal market.  This is how she earns the income she uses to support her household.  She attends to one of the stores, along with a girl who helps her, and the other store is run by her daughter and an assistant.  She is a single mother who has struggled to obtain the means to provide for her family's welfare.  She will use this loan to invest in her shoe and clothing business.  She needs to invest in products for the upcoming Christmas season.  She mentions that the previous loans that she has taken with CEPRODEL have helped her a lot, since before she only had one store and now she has two stores that are well stocked with a variety of clothing.

loans.use: to buy merchandise: clothing and shoes

loans.name: Leonarda Isabel

texts.es:
Isabel sigue con su negocio de tienda de abarrotes donde vende productos de primera necesidad como arroz,azucar,leche,aceite,tambien la socia vende utiles escolares como cuadernos,lapíceros,libros y reglas y tambien se dedica al negocio de crianza de animales como chanchos,cuyes y gallinas,por medio de este negocio la socia saca adelante a sus hijos,la socia quiere ampliar y mejorar el negocio de tienda de abarrotes y crianza de animales.La socia solicita el credito para comprar animales,productos para la tienda de abarrotes como arroz,azucar y leche y tambien para comprar utiles escolares.


La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Isabel is still running her grocery store, where she sells basic staples such as rice, sugar, milk, and oil. She also sells school supplies such as notebooks, automatic pencils, books and rulers. She also has a business raising animals such as hogs, guinea pigs and hens. This is how she is getting her children ahead. She wants to expand and improve her grocery store and her animals business. She is requesting this loan for the purchase of animals and products for her grocery store such as rice, sugar and milk, and also for school supplies.
She is happy to have this loan and promises to repay her quotas on time.

loans.use: to purchase animals; products for her grocery store, such as rice, sugar and milk; and to buy school supplies.

loans.name: Cori

texts.es: Cori, de 37 años de edad, es una mujer trabajadora y empeñosa, además de alegre y solidaria, es conviviente con Juiber, fruto de esa feliz unión tiene tres hermosos hijos de 20, 18  y 14 años de edad, habitando cómodamente una casa que es de su propiedad. La actividad que realiza Cori es la venta de comidas tales como tallarines, pollos fritos, Juanes, arroz chaufa y otros, para eso instala su mesa en el frontis de su casa todos los días por las noches hace 14 años, en donde atiende muy amablemente a sus clientes que en su mayoría son sus propios vecinos y amistades, llegando a acabar todo lo que prepara, contando con la ayuda de su hermana en la preparación y atención a los clientes, pagándole  por día trabajado. Lo que le gusta de su actividad es que le permite distraerse y estar ocupada, además de gustarle mucho el oficio de cocinar que aprendió de su madre, logrando tener una regular clientela y le deja buenas ganancias. Por lo contrario, lo que no le gusta de su actividad es cuando llueve dificulta un poco la venta, pero no se desanima,  por eso tiene planes de ampliar y mejorar su negocio, deseando abrir un restaurante en su propia casa. Este será el préstamo 4 con la institución MFP, por tanto espera de un pequeño préstamo para poder cumplir con sus objetivos. Por otro lado se compromete a ser puntal con el pago de sus cuotas, como en créditos anteriores, para así tener un buen record crediticio. Está cómoda con su grupo, pues los considera buenas personas. Con el monto solicitado de 1000 nuevos soles, desea comprar una cocina nueva, y utensilios platos, tazas.
texts.en:
Cori, age 37, is a hardworking and earnest woman.  She is also a cheerful and supportive individual.  Cori is in a happy common-law relationship with Juiber and they have three beautiful children (ages 20, 18, and 14).  They live comfortably in their own home.  Cori sells food such as noodles, fried chicken, “juanes” (chicken and rice wrapped in banana leaves), fried rice, and other dishes.  She has a table set up in front of her house where she has been selling in the evenings every day of the week for the past 14 years.  Cori provides friendly service to her customers, most of whom are neighbors and friends.  They come to buy everything she prepares.  Her sister helps with preparing food and attending to the customers.  She is paid every day she works.  Cori enjoys her business because it provides a distraction and keeps her busy.  In addition, she likes to cook because she learned this skill for her mother.  She has accumulated regular customers and earns a good income.  On the other hand, she dislikes operating her business when it rains because she generates few sales.  This does not discourage her and she has plans to expand and improve her business.  She wants to open a restaurant in her home.

This will be her fourth loan with the MFP organization.  She hopes that this small loan will enable her to complete her goals.  In addition, Cori promises to be punctual with her payments just like she did with her previous loans.  She has a good credit record.  Cori is comfortable with her group because she considers the members to be good people.  The amount of 1000 PEN that she is requesting will be used to buy a new stove, utensils, plates, and cups.

loans.use: to buy a new stove, utensils, plates, and cups.

loans.name: Nargila

texts.en:
Nargila is 41 years old. She is from the village of Beitarabchi, East Georgia. Nargila lives with her 21-year-old son and retired mother. Nargila and her son lead the family's agricultural business. They have a milk cow, five calves and ten sheep. The family sells dairy products and lambs on the local market. In addition, Nargila’s family owns four hectares of land where different corns and vegetables are grown, which are also sold locally. The family's total average monthly income is 600 Laris.
Nargila has requested credit for cultivating the land. After cultivation, Nargila will sow corn and vegetables.
